DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump is said to be preparing USD 60bln package of tariffs on China that could be announced by Friday. (Newswires)

South Korean PPI Growth (Feb) Y/Y 1.3% (Prev. 1.2%). (Newswires)

New Zealand Westpac Consumer Survey (Q1) 111.2 (Prev. 107.4). (Newswires)
 

UK

UK and EU reached an agreement on Brexit transition terms according to the EU Commission, Furthermore, separate reports stated that the UK would continue implementing all EU rules under the jurisdiction of the bloc’s top court until the end of 2020 and that agreement on transition, citizens' rights and financial settlement has been made. Also, it was noted that the Ireland issue remains but an agreement is said to have been reached on Irish border "backstop" agreement. (Newswires)
 

EU

ECB policymakers broadly comfortable with market pricing of first rate hike in Q2 2019 and shifting debate to steepness of rate path as even doves accept that QE should end this year, according to sources. (Newswires)

ECB’s Mersch said ECB has become more confident in inflation and noted all conditions for inflation to move target are in place, but also stated that it still requires expansionary monetary policy measures. (Newswires)

German Economy Minister Altmaier said after talks with US Commerce Secretary Ross, they both think a solution to planned tariffs on steel and aluminium is possible. Furthermore, there were separate reports that the US is said to have asked EU to meet 5 conditions to gain tariff exemption. (Newswires)

 

FX

Canadian PM Trudeau said President Trump seems enthusiastic about getting a NAFTA deal done, while Canada’s NAFTA negotiator Morneau said making progress on NAFTA and that consensus among 3 partners is to reach a deal quickly. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

OPEC / Non-OPEC are said to see record compliance in February. (Newswires)

Saudi oil exports rose to 7.170mln bpd (Jan) vs. Prev. 7.045mln bpd (Dec). (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said the worst is over in oil market and focus remains on output pact that runs to the end of 2018. (Newswires)

 

US

US Treasury official said that President Trump has belief in free trade but at the G20 Mnuchin is making clear that the US won't give up national interests for a functioning free trade system. (Newswires)

US President Trump's lawyers have submitted some documents to Special Counsel Mueller as they seek to limit scope of potential Trump questioning. (Washington Post)

President Trump to support health subsidies in the omnibus spending bill. (Washington Post)

Freedom Caucus Chair Meadows said he doesn't see a shutdown happening this week. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Risk-off sentiment saw stock indices drop ahead of this week’s key risk events (Fed, BOE, RBNZ, Brexit-related events). Monday’s weakness was led by tech shares with Facebook (FB) down heavily after a data breach, and Apple (AAPL) weighing on the tech sector after reports that it plans to develop its own micro LED screens. SPX -1.42% at 2713, DJI -1.34% at 24611, NDX -2.21% at 6865.

Ahead of FOMC, the fixed income was taking its cue from the risk-tone. The T-Note was taking its lead from the Bund in early US trade, heading south after hawkish ECB sources. However, after touching 120-02, the T-Note began to find buyers, rising towards 120-16.

UBS Weekly FX Flows - EUR & JPY bid amid weak risk sentiment
content:
• EURUSD: Asset managers and hedge fund managers were leading buying in EURUSD, outweighing selling from private clients and corporations, UBS said.
  • USDJPY: Heavy yen buying offset private clients selling of the yen.
  • EURJPY: UBS saw net inflows led by asset managers and supported by corporate and private clients.
  • GBPUSD: Asset managers and hedge funds were sellers, there was moderate buying from corporate and private clients.
  • EURGBP: flat flows.
  • EURCHF: Asset managers and hedge funds were buyers amid corporate/private selling, though flows were flat.
  • USDCHF: UBS saw net selling by all client groups except hedge funds, who were net long.
  • AUDUSD: Being sold as heavy selling from corporates exceeded the buys from other groups.
  • NZDUSD: Net bought from modest inflows on every client base.
  • USDCAD: CAD sold against USD with hedge funds showing strong selling interest, whereas other client groups were more or less flat.
  • EURSEK: Saw inflows for the first time in 8 weeks as buying from asset managers and hedge funds outweighed modest selling from corporates.
  • EURNOK: UBS note this was also bought, led by asset managers and private clients.
  • USDSEK: Saw buying for the second straight week led by asset managers as corporate and private clients showed limited direction
  • USDNOK: Saw buying for the fourth straight week led by asset managers as corporate and private clients showed limited direction

subject: US MARKET WRAP: Risk-off and Brexit transition agreement
content:
• SNAPSHOT: Equities Down; USD down; EUR up; GBP up; Treasuries up; Crude up
  • REAR VIEW: Provisional Brexit transition agreement; ECB shift toward steepness of rate path
  • AHEAD: UK CPI; EU Consumer Confidence

* EQUITIES: SPX -1.42% at 2713, DJI -1.34% at 24611, NDX -2.21% at 6865

* SECTORS: CONS DISC (XLY): -0.93%, CONS STAP (XLP): -0.95%, ENERGY (XLE): -1.74%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -0.64%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -1.34%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -0.74%, MATERIALS (XLB): -1.20%, TECH (XLK): -1.97%, TELECOMS (XTL): -0.56%, UTILITIES (XLU): -0.58%

* EQUITIES: Risk-off sentiment saw stock indices drop ahead of this week’s key risk events (Fed, BOE, RBNZ, Brexit-related events). Monday’s weakness was led by tech shares with Facebook (FB) down heavily after a data breach, and Apple (AAPL) weighing on the tech sector after reports that it plans to develop its own micro LED screens.

* USD lower amid a risk-off tone, which saw flows into safe havens (though less so the T-Note). The DXY dropped beneath the 90-handle, closing below the 90 level as we head into APAC trade.

* GBP saw strong moves after news that the UK had provisionally agreed a transition deal; however, the Irish border issue is still to be resolved. EU ministers will evaluate the situation on Friday before signing-off, which will allow the UK to move onto talks on a future relationship with the EU. Cable, rose past the key level of 1.4020, to a highs just beneath 1.41. Data ahead such as UK CPI on Tuesday will now be driving GBP following pound-positive Brexit news.

* EUR ticked-up sharply after sources reported that the ECB is comfortable with the market pricing a first rate hike in Q2 2019 with the debate shifting towards the steepness of the rate path looking in to the future, as QE resoundingly being agreed to end this year. This led to stops being tripped through the 1.23 level and saw sustained EUR strength into market close, with the USDEUR knocking around 1.2350.

* JPY saw overnight strengthening after poor approval stats for PM Abe amid the cronyism scandal. But USDJPY came off the overnight lows in European trade with the 106.20 level remaining a focus. Nevertheless, as the risk tone soured, USDJPY resumed declines, though the 1056.75 level provided support.

* CAD caught a bid after positive comments from Canadian finance minister Morneau said NAFTA talks were making progress, and there is a consensus among partners to reach a deal quickly. USDCAD probed lower levels, though support around 1.3050 was strong.

* TREASURIES: 10 YEAR T-NOTE FUTURES (JUNE 2018) SETTLES UP 1+ TICKS AT 120-12+. Ahead of FOMC, the fixed income was taking its cue from the risk-tone. The T-Note was taking its lead from the Bund in early US trade, heading south after hawkish ECB sources. However, after touching 120-02, the T-Note began to find buyers, rising towards 120-16.

* Crude saw a large fall after the US open on risk-off tone of trade. Those losses were pared back, with some suggesting that this on reports that the US was exploring sanctions on Venezuelan oil. Elsewhere JODI reported Saudi oil exports increased Saudi oil exports from 7.045mln bpd to 7.170mln bpd adding to the over-supply narrative. We also had OPEC Secretary General Barkindo stating that the worst in the oil market is over. Meanwhile, Japanese crude oil imports for February fell by 13.8% YoY to 3.16mln bpd. Ahead of this week's inventories, Genscape was said to have reported a build at Cushing of 22k, hinting at a second consecutive build at the hub.

Daily FX Wrap: Brexit breakthrough and ECB sources liven up proceedings
content: Markets looked pretty settled into a pre-Fed vigil, albeit with existing themes and trends intact (Jpy still bucking the wider pattern of G10 losses vs the Greenback on safe-haven demand due to PM Abe’s sliding popularity amidst the land sale scandal), but were jolted by latest Brexit developments and a hawkish ECB piece penned by 5 ‘sources’ said to be in the know. In short, the UK and EU held an emergency meeting ahead of the end of week Summit, with a press statement set for 11.45GMT. Cable started to climb and Eur/Gbp decline in the run up and expectation that a positive update on transition negotiations would be forthcoming, and Sterling bulls were not disappointed as a broad agreement with an Irish border back-stop was unveiled. Cable got to 1.4088 and Eur/Gbp just dipped below 0.8750 support, but the latter quickly based and bounced on the aforementioned ECB story that essentially ratified market rate expectations for a tightening around Q2 next year and a complete termination of QE by the end of 2018. Eur/Gbp has recovered towards 0.8780 and Eur/Usd rebounded over 1.2300 to circa 1.2325. Meanwhile, some positive NAFTA comments from Canada’s Morneau (talks progressing and consensus for a swift accord) helped the underperforming Cad and Mxn pare some recent losses with the Loonie back above 1.3100 vs the Usd from 1.3125 lows. A slightly less risk-off tone as a result of all the above lifted Usd/Jpy to higher peaks over 106.00 at one stage (around 106.30 to be more precise), but yet again the big figure proves to be magnetic and exerted a gravitational pull. As a result of all the above, the DXY failed to build further on early gains and challenge 90.500 nearest resistance, before easing back below 90.000 and now looking for some respite if not renewed momentum to continue its recovery.

subject: EU DEBT LATEST: double whammy for bond sellers
content: Bunds and Gilts hitting fresh session lows as hawkish ECB source reports compound the broad Brexit transition deal news, with the former down to 157.67 and latter just off a 121.14 base, 52 and 77 ticks below last Friday’s respective Eurex and Liffe closes. Chart-wise, Bunds may see stops tripped if 157.65 is breached, with support after that at 157.47, 157.34 and then 157.17, which was last Tuesday’s low. For Gilts, there is nothing much after the 121.00 level until 120.89, and no strong tech support before 120.48, which incorporates early March and late February lows. Elsewhere, 10s USTs are looking precarious having only just bounced off 120-025 support ahead of 120-00 and following more bearish option positioning focusing on the 119-00 strike.

subject: As Barnier continues to speak, GBP/USD continues to push higher as markets view the developments on a transition agreement as positive; gilts are also trading at session lows
analysis_details:
• Barnier confirmed that a transition agreement had been agreed which should give UK businesses some certainty ahead of the UK exit of the EU in March 2019. 
  • Furthermore, Davis said the UK will be able to negotiate and sign trade deals during the transition which can come into force as soon as the transition period ends. 
  • However, EUR/GBP found some support after the ECB sources story which suggested even the most dovish members are in favour of ending QE this year and that policy makers are comfortable with market pricing of a hike in Q2 2019. 
  • Some focus has been placed on the specific language being used within the draft agreement which states that "the United Kingdom may negotiate, sign and ratify international agreements entered into its own capacity in the areas of exclusive competence of the Union, provided those agreements do not enter into force or apply during the transition period, unless so authorised by the union"

subject: Canada’s NAFTA negotiator Morneau says making progress on NAFTA, consensus among 3 partners to reach a deal quickly

ECB policymakers broadly comfortable with market pricing of first rate hike in Q2 2019 and shifting debate to steepness of rate path as even doves accept that QE should end this year, according to sources
reaction_details: • In immediate reaction EUR/USD rose 27 pips from 1.2285 to 1.2312 while Bunds fell 15 ticks from 157.99 to 157.84.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European bourses started the week on a poor footing (Eurostoxx 50 -1.0%) as investors anticipate a hawkish Fed meeting later this week.
content:
19th March 2018

  • European bourses started the week on a poor footing (Eurostoxx 50 -1.0%) as investors anticipate a hawkish Fed meeting later this week.
  • GBP seen higher amid reports that the EU have agreed on the broad terms of UK transition deal
  • Looking ahead, today’s session sees a lack of tier 1 highlights

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed with the region indecisive ahead of a widely anticipated Fed rate hike this week. ASX 200 (+0.2%) finished positive as strength in energy kept the index afloat, while Nikkei 225 (-1.0%) underperformed amid a firmer JPY and as support for PM Abe’s administration slumped to 33% (Prev. 45%) in the wake of the land-sale scandal. KOSPI (-0.8%) suffered losses in its top-weighted stocks in which Samsung Electronics fell on news Apple is to develop displays to replace Samsung screens, while Hyundai Motor was hit by a stateside investigation into fatal incidents involving airbag failure which could affect a total of 425K Hyundai and Kia cars. Hang Seng (flat) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were indecisive and traded choppy amid mixed property data from China, a neutral PBoC open market operation and after China signalled stable monetary policy continuity as it chose PBoC Deputy Governor Yi Gang to be the next central bank head. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid an indecisive risk-tone in the region, while an unsurprising Summary of Opinions release and unchanged Rinban announcement also kept prices range-bound. As such, Japanese yields were mixed while their US counterparts were higher ahead of the FOMC in which the US 2-year yield rose to its highest since 2008.

China approved the nomination of PBoC Deputy Governor Yi Gang to be the next PBoC Governor, while China also nominated former Vice-Finance Minister Liu Kun to be the new Finance Minister and nominated Hu Chunhua and Xi economic advisor Liu He for Vice Premier positions. (Newswires). Incoming PBoC Governor Yi Gang said that China is to maintain prudent monetary policy and will continue to open up, while he added China will launch a series of opening up measures. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos, for a net neutral position on the day as injections equalled maturing operations. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3320 (Prev. 6.3340)

China House Prices (Feb) Y/Y 5.2% (Prev. 5.0%); China Property Prices rose M/M in 44 out of 70 cities (Prev. 52) and rose Y/Y in 59 out of 70 cities (Prev. 59). (Newswires)

GLOBAL NEWS

As widely expected, Vladimir Putin has won the Russian Presidential election with a landslide victory. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB's Knot said inflation has been fairly stable so that provides a high degree confidence that actually inflation will pick up and will at some point approach the definition of price stability. (Newswires)

ECB’s Weidmann said he thinks that good economy developments and inflation would permit a rapid end to bond purchases. (Newswires)

ECB’s Villeroy commented that the progress to inflation target was slower than anticipated. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

White House lawyer Cobb stated the administration is not considering or discussing firing Special Counsel Mueller. (Newswires)

45 US trade groups urged President Donald Trump to not place tariffs on China, which they warned would harm the US economy and consumers. (Newswires)

EU have agreed on the broad terms of UK transition deal, but Ireland issue remains, according to WSJ. (WSJ)

 

According to an IHS Markit survey, household incomes are rising at near their fastest pace since the financial crisis in 2009 with some speculating this could force the BoE to lift rates again soon. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

The EU published tariff lists in response to US tariffs on aluminium and steel which was said to be for stakeholder consultations and could affect EUR  6.4bln in US exports.  (Newswires)

Japan PM Abe reportedly asked South Korea President Moon to help set up a meeting with North Korea Leader Kim. (Dong-A)

EQUITIES

Despite a mixed Asia-Pacific trading session, European bourses started the week on a poor footing (Eurostoxx 50 -0.7%) as investors anticipate a hawkish Fed meeting later this week. Energy and materials are amongst the worst performing sectors as concerns of US drilling activity points to higher output. Mining names are feeling the pressure from a firmer dollar with Antofagasta (-2.9%), Anglo American (2.8%), BHP (-2.7%), Rio (-2.5%) all seen at the foot of the FTSE 100; FSTE also hampered by the firmer GBP. On the flip side, the financial sector is outperforming with Barclays (+3.8%) higher after reports that activist investor, Sherborne Investors have acquired a 5.2% stake in the bank. Additionally, SocGen (+1.0%) is providing some support to the sector after the Co. said they expect resolution over the LIBOR probe in the coming weeks. Separately, sources stated the company is applying for a banking license in Australia. In terms of individual movers, Hammerson shares leapt 26% after the Co. rejected a GBP 5bln offer from French retail property developer Klepierre (-3.4%). Micro Focus (-55.6%) plummeted to the bottom of the Stoxx 600 following a double whammy from worse than expected revenue outlook and the departure of their short-lived CEO.

FX

Although Usd/Jpy remains capped at 106.00 or just above (on decline in PM Abe’s rating and broader global trade concerns), the Greenback has extended recovery gains vs the rest of the G10, other majors and EM currency counterparts. Indeed, the DXY looks relatively underpinned and more comfortable above 90.000, eyeing interim and psychological resistance at 90.500 following last Friday’s big IP data beat and a think tank report suggesting that the FOMC may well start prepping the market for the prospect of 4 rather than 3 hikes this year after an almost unanimously anticipated 1st 25 bp tightening this week. The Greenback is especially bid vs the commodity bloc, as Usd/Cad breaches upside tech objectives in the low 1.3100 area to target 1.3132 next (61.8% Fib retracement), while Aud/Usd has now lost the 0.7700 handle and is looking at 0.7680 near term support as weakness in iron ore prices compound the pair’s sharp retreat. Nzd/Usd is only just keeping tabs with the 0.7200 level and a prominent UK bank is predicting further downside via a trade of the week targeting 0.7130 with a 0.7315 stop. Usd/Chf is in a 0.9550-20 range and Eur/Chf is still hugging the 1.1700 marker amidst some speculation that the SNB is on the bid below the figure. Cable has rallied firmly above 1.4000 and through interim resistance at 1.4020 from just over 1.3900 at the overnight low and Eur/Gbp has retreated through 0.8800 to 0.8760 ahead of a Brexit statement from the EU (11.45GMT) after hastily arranged emergency convene before this week’s key Summit. Eur/Usd has bounced mildly from a 1.2260 low and reclaimed a key Fib around 1.2666 in the process amidst some upbeat ECB rhetoric on growth and inflation. Ahead of the Fed, the G20 meeting will be in focus for any further trade war/protectionism verbal exchanges, beyond the draft communique already circulated last week.

FIXED INCOME

Core bonds are deriving some support from the relatively steep pull-back in EU stocks, with Bunds paring losses to just 5 ticks vs 18 ticks at one stage, and perhaps more poignantly holding in above the 158.00 level, albeit just. Note, last Friday’s Eurex session low was 157.98 and stops are seen on a break down to 157.81, while resistance via a market contact sits just above the early intraday high at 158.23 and ahead of the peak from the previous session at 158.35. However, Gilts still lagging/underperforming only a handful of ticks off worst levels (121.51, -40 ticks) and awaiting confirmation of reports that the UK and EU have agreed Brexit transition details, while USTs remain heavy after last week’s strong run of data and hedging/positioning defensively for a hawkish Fed, ie 2 year yield now above 2.30% and 3 month Libor continuing its squeeze higher (2.20%+, and perhaps nearer 2.22% at today’s fix?). Looking at 10 year Treasuries from a tech perspective, 120-06+ forms rising trend-line support below last Friday’s 120-08+ base and before 120-03, which protects the 120-00 level.

COMMODITIES

Looking at the commodities complex, WTI (-0.6%) and Brent (-0.7%) are pressured by concerns of oversupply arising as US drilling activity increases. The weekly Baker Hughes rig count added four oil rigs on Friday bringing the total oil rig number to 800 compared to 631 a year ago.  Moving on to metals, Gold (-0.1%) continued to edge lower on a firmer dollar but has seen a slight bounce in recent trade. Dalian iron ore fell by 4% to its lowest level since November weighed by high inventories and weaker steel demand.

Russian Energy Minister Novak affirmed pledge to see OPEC production deal through to the end and reiterated that Russia is willing to extend cuts if necessary, while he added that Russia is open to discussing phase-out from the deal when appropriate. (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said they’re beginning to see that stability is gradually returning to the oil market. (Newswires)

subject: EU have agreed on the broad terms of UK transition deal, but Ireland issue remains
content:
• U.K. would continue implementing all EU rules under the jurisdiction of the bloc’s top court until the end of 2020.
  • Agreement on transition, citizens' rights, financial settlement have been agreed
  • An agreement is said to have been reached on Irish border "backstop" agreement.

subject: GBP/USD is gaining a firmer footing above 1.4000 after recently breaching the level amid ongoing optimism that the UK can finalise details of transition arrangements
analysis_details:
• This comes in the context of UK Brexit Secretary Davis meeting with EU Chief negotiator Barnier today in Brussels ahead of Thursday's crunch meeting on Thursday. 
  •  Furthermore, the deputy Irish PM has recently tweeted "Good meeting with @MichelBarnier again this morning - #Brexit negotiations are moving forward - progress on Irish issues remains a key priority for both negotiating teams and solidarity with our EU partners remains strong."
  • Note, an announcement by the EU on the matter is due at `1145GMT
  • Alongside the firmer GBP, the FSTE sits at session lows

content: A relatively tame start to the week in terms of price movement, as the 10 year German benchmark straddles last Friday’s 158.19 Eurex close within a 158.07-21 range, albeit mostly on the downside in line with extended US Treasury losses in wake of significantly stronger than expected IP data and a hawkish advisory note suggesting that the Fed could raise its dot plots to indicate 4 hikes this year from 3 previously. Meanwhile, a couple of more hawkish/less concerned ECB views on the inflation outlook despite latest figures showing softer than forecast price gauges, with Weidmann particularly confident that economic and inflation momentum are strong enough to warrant a swift end to QE (somewhat at odds with recent commentary indicating a steady withdrawal after September.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from GKN, RBS, Bayer and Dailmer
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

19th March 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

FTSE

GKN (GKN LN) – Lancaster Investment, a major shareholder in GKN, is opposed to a hostile takeover by Melrose (MRO LN). Separately, Melrose has offered to invest GBP 1bln in GKN’s pension fund. This comes after GKN rejected Melrose’s final offer of GBP 8.1bln. (FT)

UK gambling names – a trio of MPs said maximum bets on fixed-odd betting terminals (FOBTs) should be cut from GBP 100 to GBP 2 pre spin. This cap could lead to a GBP 5.5bln loss in tax revenues over the next 10 years; according to a government estimate. Separately, the Gambling Commission is to recommend that the government reduces the maximum bet on fixed-odds betting terminals (FOBTs) to GBP 30 or less (BBC/FT)

RBS (RBS LN) - Shareholders have won a battle that lasted two years to force the Co. to hold a vote to give investors more power regarding executive pay and other controversial issues. (FT)

Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN) – Co. has joined the race to build energy storage batteries with materials usually designed for hard-wearing contact-lenses, cooperating with a research co. Superdielectrics, with the aim of dominating traditional batteries. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

UNILEVER (ULVR LN) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM SELL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

CLOSE BROTHERS (CBG LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERG

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets traded mixed with the region indecisive ahead of a widely anticipated Fed rate hike this week
content:
• Asian equity markets traded mixed with the region indecisive ahead of a widely anticipated Fed rate hike this week
  • China signalled stable monetary policy continuity as it chose PBoC Deputy Governor Yi Gang to be the next central bank head
  • Looking ahead, today’s session sees a lack of tier 1 highlights

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed with the region indecisive ahead of a widely anticipated Fed rate hike this week. ASX 200 (+0.2%) finished positive as strength in energy kept the index afloat, while Nikkei 225 (-1.0%) underperformed amid a firmer JPY and as support for PM Abe’s administration slumped to 33% (Prev. 45%) in the wake of the land-sale scandal. KOSPI (-0.8%) suffered losses in its top-weighted stocks in which Samsung Electronics fell on news Apple is to develop displays to replace Samsung screens, while Hyundai Motor was hit by a stateside investigation into fatal incidents involving airbag failure which could affect a total of 425K Hyundai and Kia cars. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were indecisive and traded choppy amid mixed property data from China, a neutral PBoC open market operation and after China signalled stable monetary policy continuity as it chose PBoC Deputy Governor Yi Gang to be the next central bank head. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid an indecisive risk-tone in the region, while an unsurprising Summary of Opinions release and unchanged Rinban announcement also kept prices range-bound. As such, Japanese yields were mixed while their US counterparts were higher ahead of the FOMC in which the US 2-year yield rose to its highest since 2008.

China approved the nomination of PBoC Deputy Governor Yi Gang to be the next PBoC Governor, while China also nominated former Vice-Finance Minister Liu Kun to be the new Finance Minister and nominated Hu Chunhua and Xi economic advisor Liu He for Vice Premier positions. (Newswires) Incoming PBoC Governor Yi Gang said that China is to maintain prudent monetary policy and will continue to open up, while he added China will launch a series of opening up measures. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos, for a net neutral position on the day as injections equalled maturing operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3320 (Prev. 6.3340)

China House Prices (Feb) Y/Y 5.2% (Prev. 5.0%); China Property Prices rose M/M in 44 out of 70 cities (Prev. 52) and rose Y/Y in 59 out of 70 cities (Prev. 59). (Newswires)

BoJ Summary of Opinions for March 8th-9th meeting states that it is appropriate to pursue powerful monetary easing with persistence under the current guideline and that the effects of monetary easing measures will be enhanced with inflation rate increasing towards target and the potential growth rate rising going forward. There was also the opinion that additional monetary easing will be needed if there is a heightened risk that achieving the price stability target will be delayed but that fiscal policy is also required as there is not ample room for further monetary easing. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Irish PM Varadkar suggested optimism on reaching a conclusion regarding the Irish border issue. (Newswires)

ECB’s Weidmann said he thinks that good economy developments and inflation would permit a rapid end to bond purchases. (Newswires)

ECB’s Villeroy commented that the progress to inflation target was slower than anticipated. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Mar) M/M 1.5% (Prev. 0.8%). (Newswires)
UK Rightmove House Prices (Mar) Y/Y 2.1% (Prev. 1.5%)

The UK Brexit Select Committee is set to recommend that the UK should request an extension to the EU's Article 50 process beyond March 2019. (Newswires)

According to an HIS Markit survey, household incomes are rising at near their fastest pace since the financial crisis in 2009 with some speculating this could force the BoE to lift rates again soon. (Newswires)

The UK’s BCC has raised its GDP forecast for 2018 from 1.1% to 1.4% and in 2019 from 1.3% to 1.5%. Its first forecast for 2020 is for 1.6% growth. (BBC)

As widely expected, Vladimir Putin has won the Russian Presidential election with a landslide victory. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Austria at AA+; Outlook Stable and affirmed Denmark at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires) Fitch affirmed Italy at BBB; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

The greenback remained firmer with the DXY above the 90.00 level after last Friday’s stronger than expected Industrial Production and ahead of a widely expected rate hike from the Fed. This pressured its counterparts across the board with commodity-linked currencies also kept subdued by weakness in the metals complex, while USD/HKD rose to print a fresh 33yr high. Conversely, JPY was the exception and outpaced the USD amid the indecisive risk-tone and after USD/JPY failed to hold onto the 106.00 handle.

COMMODITIES

Commodity prices were lacklustre overnight in which WTI crude futures pulled back from Friday’s gains and briefly slipped to below USD 62/bbl. Elsewhere, gold languished as the greenback remained firm ahead of the looming FOMC, while copper extended on last week’s lows alongside the indecisive risk tone and early weakness in Chinese metals prices in which Dalian iron ore futures slipped over 3% shortly after the open. 

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (15 Mar) 990 (Prev. 984). (Newswires)
US Baker Hughes Oil Rig Count (15 Mar) 800 (Prev. 796)
US Baker Hughes Gas Rig Count (15 Mar) 189 (Prev. 188)

Russian Energy Minister Novak affirmed pledge to see OPEC production deal through to the end and reiterated that Russia is willing to extend cuts if necessary, while he added that Russia is open to discussing phase-out from the deal when appropriate. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Japan PM Abe reportedly asked South Korea President Moon to help set up a meeting with North Korea Leader Kim. (Dong-A)

White House said that US President Trump told South Korean President Moon that still on track to meet with North Korean Supreme Leader Kim by May. (Newswires)

UK, France and Germany have proposed new EU sanctions on Iran to aim to keep US President Trump committed to the Iranian nuclear deal, while reports added that sanctions would target individuals involved in ballistic weapons activity and war in Syria. (Newswires)

US

Yields were higher across the curve after the relatively strong data saw a sell-off in bonds in relatively good volume. However, volume and flows dried out at the end of the day and Treasuries meandered into the close. At the pit close. Jun T-notes settled at 120.11, down 5 ticks.

White House said US President Trump is negotiating with individual countries regarding tariffs and will continue to negotiate on exemptions through next week, while there were also reports that US government is to accept tariff exclusion requests from today. In related news, the EU published tariff lists in response to US tariffs on aluminium and steel which was said to be for stakeholder consultations and could affect EUR  6.4bln in US exports.  (Newswires)

45 US trade groups urged President Donald Trump to not place tariffs on China, which they warned would harm the US economy and consumers. (Newswires)

White House lawyer Cobb stated the administration is not considering or discussing firing Special Counsel Mueller. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID SESSION UPDATE: Asia begins FOMC week mixed
content:
Asia equity markets trade mixed with the region indecisive ahead of a widely anticipated Fed rate hike this week. ASX 200 (+0.2%) is choppy with strength in energy just about keeping the index afloat, while Nikkei 225 (-0.9%) underperforms amid a firmer JPY and with support for PM Abe’s administration slumping to 33% (Prev. 45%) in the wake of the land-sale scandal. KOSPI is subdued by losses in the index’s top-weighted stocks with Samsung Electronics reeling on news that Apple is to develop displays to replace Samsung screens, while Hyundai Motor is hit by a stateside investigation into 4 fatal incidents due to airbag failure which could impact as much as 425K Hyundai and Kia cars. Elsewhere, Hang Seng and Shanghai Comp are indecisive and trade relatively flat amid mixed property data from China, a neutral PBoC open market operation and after China signalled stable monetary policy continuity as it chose PBoC Deputy Governor Yi Gang to be the next central bank head.

In FX markets, the greenback remains firmer with the DXY above the 90.00 level after last Friday’s stronger than expected Industrial Production and ahead of a widely expected rate hike from the Fed. This pressured most of its counterparts with EUR/USD once again taking the brunt of the moves and with commodity-linked currencies also kept subdued by weakness in the metals complex, while USD/HKD rose to print a fresh 33yr high. Conversely, JPY was the exception and out-strengthened USD amid the indecisive risk-tone and after USD/JPY failed to hold onto the 106.00 handle.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat amid an indecisive risk-tone in the region, while an unsurprising Summary of Opinions release and unchanged Rinban announcement also contributed to the directionless trade. As such, Japanese yields are mixed while their US counterparts are higher ahead of the FOMC in which the US 2-year yield rose to its highest since 2008.
